tuv.seg: Classification of crimes in criminal cases
Coireanna a aicmiú i gcúiseanna coiriúla
A crime is defined in law in Ireland as an act which may be punished by the State
De réir dlí na hÉireann, is í coir ná gníomhaíocht inphionóis
The way in which a criminal offence is investigated and prosecuted depends on the type of crime involved
Déantar imscrúdú ar chion coiriúil agus déantar é a ionchúiseamh bunaithe ar an gcineál coire atá i gceist
For these purposes criminal offences may be described in different ways such as:
Chun na críche seo, féadtar cionta coiriúla a aicmiú mar seo a leanas:
Summary and indictable offences
Cionta Achomair agus Indíotáilte
There are two ways criminal offences can be tried in Irish law:
Úsáidtear dhá mhodh chun cionta coiriúla a thriail in Éirinn:
• In the lower court (District Court) before a judge without a jury
• I gcúirteanna áitiúla (Cúirt Dúiche), os comhair breithimh ach gan coiste dháréag a bheith i láthair
• In the higher courts (Circuit Criminal Court, Central Criminal Court) before a judge and jury
• I gcúirteanna náisiúnta (An Chúirt Chuarda Choiriúil, An Phríomhchúirt Choiriúil) os comhair breithimh agus coiste dháréag
Summary and indictable offences indicate the manner in which these offences are tried or dealt with in the courts
Léiríonn teideal na gcionta – cionta achomair agus indíotáilte – an tslí ina ndéantar na cionta seo a thriail nó a phlé sna cúirteanna

A summary offence is one which can only be dealt with by a judge sitting without a jury,that is the District Court, while an indictable offence is one which may be or must be tried before a judge and jury
Caithfear cion achomair a phlé os comhair breithimh gan coiste dháréag a bheith i láthair - an Chúirt Dúiche - ach caithfear cion indíotáilte a thriail os comhair breithimh agus coiste dháréag
All common-law offences are held to be indictable offences as the common law did not distinguish or differentiate between indictable and non-indictable offences
Féachtar ar chionta faoin dlí coiteann mar chionta indíotáilte, toisc nár leagadh amach difríochtaí idir cionta indíotáilte agus cionta neamhindíotáilte faoin dlí coiteann

However, criminal statutes or criminal laws passed into law by the Oireachtas do make a distinction between types of crimes and therefore differentiates on how different crimes will be dealt with by the courts

Leagtar amach na difríochtaí seo áfach sna reachtanna nó sna dlíthe coiriúla a chur an Oireachtas i bhfeidhm. Soláthraíonn na hathruithe seo faisnéis ar na modhanna difriúla a n-úsáidtear sna cúirteanna chun déileáil le coireanna difriúla
When an offence is dealt with in a District Court, the judge is restricted in the length of sentence they can impose for any offence
Nuair a dhéantar cion a phlé sa Chúirt Dúiche, níl cead ag an mbreitheamh pianbhreith ró-fhada a chur ar dhuine de bharr ciona amháin

The Criminal Justice Act 1984 (Section11) states that the maximum term of imprisonment that can be imposed by the District Court in respect of any number of offences for which sentence is passed at the same time cannot exceed 2 years
De réir an Achta um Cheartas Coiriúil 1984 (Alt 11) níl cead ag an gCúirt Dúiche téarma príosúnachta de níos mó ná dhá bhliain a thabhairt do dhuine i leith ciona amháin nó níos mó ná cion amháin
Similarly, the District Court cannot exceed a maximum sentence of 1 year in respect of one offence
Ar an gcuma chéanna, níl cead ag Cúirt Dúiche téarma príosúnachta de níos mó ná bliain amháin a thabhairt do dhuine i leith ciona amháin
Examples of summary offences are:
Is iad seo a leanas roinnt chionta achomair:
• Public Order Offence – Begging in an intimidating or threatening manner
• Cion Oird Phoiblí – Ag lorg déirce ar bhealach is cúis le himeagla nó le bagairt
The penalty for being found guilty of this offence is a class E fine or up to one month in prison or both a fine and a term of imprisonment
Pionós de rang E fíneáil atá ciontach nó téarma príosúnachta de mí amháin, nó an dá rud
• Public Order Offence- Threatening abusive or insulting behaviour in a public place
• Cion Oird Phoiblí – Iompar a d’fhéadfadh a bheith bagrach don bheatha, iompar aibheiseach nó maslaitheach in áit phoiblí
The penalty available to a judge where a person is found guilty of this offence is a class D fine or up to three months in prison or both a fine and a term of imprisonment
Tá cead ag an mbreitheamh pionós de rang D fíneáil a thabhairt amach don té atá ciontach, nó téarma príosúnachta de thrí mhí, nó an dá rud
Are all indictable offences tried in the higher courts?
An ndéantar cionta indíotáilte a thriail i gcúirteanna náisiúnta?
Indictable offences are those which may or must be tried on indictment before a judge and jury, that is, in the Circuit Court or the Central Criminal Court
Is iad cionta indíotáilte ná cionta a fhéadfar nó a gcaithfear a thriail ar díotáil os comhair breithimh agus coiste dháréag – sa Chúirt Chuarda nó sa Phríomhchúirt Choiriúil
However, not all indictable offences are tried before a jury
Ní dhéantar gach cion indíotáilte a thriail os comhair coiste dháréag áfach
Indictable offences can be divided into a number of categories
Féadtar cionta indíotáilte a chur i roinnt chatagóirí difriúla
A) Offences which must always be tried on indictment
A) Caithfear na cionta seo a leanas a thriail ar díotáil i gcónaí

There are a number of offences which must be tried before a judge and jury and these offences are listed in the Criminal Procedure Act 1967 and the Criminal Law (Rape) (Amendment) Act 1990. These include:

Caithfear roinnt chionta a thriail os comhair breithimh agus coiste dháréag. Luaitear na cionta seo san Acht um Nós Imeachta Coiriúil 1967 agus san Acht um Dhlí Choiriúil (Éigniú) (Leasú) 1990, mar shampla:
• Offence under the Treason Act 1939
• Cionta faoin Acht Um Thréas 1939
• Murder, attempted murder, conspiracy to murder
• Dúnmharú, iarracht ar dhúnmharú, comhcheilg chun dúnmharú a dhéanamh
In addition to the above there are a number of offences which do not include an option to be dealt with in the District Court (summary disposal)
I dteannta leis na cionta thuasluaite, ní fhéadtar roinnt chionta a thriail sa Chúirt Dúiche (achoimre a chur de láimh)
They must be dealt with on indictment. Examples of these are:
Caithfear déileáil leis na cionta seo ar díotáil, mar shampla:
• Section 4 of the Non Fatal Offences Against the Person Act 1997 – Assault causing serious harm
• Alt 4 den Acht um Chionta Neamh-Mharfacha in Aghaidh an Duine 1997 – Ionsaí tromchúiseach
The penalty on conviction on indictment is a fine or imprisonment for life or both
Má dhéantar an té atá ciontach a chiontú, caithfear pionós a íoc, cuirtear príosúnacht lena shaol air nó an dá rud
The statute (or piece of law) does not allow for this offence to be dealt with summarily
De réir an reachta (nó ailt dlí) seo, ní fhéadtar déileáil leis an gcion seo go hachomair
• Section 14 of the Criminal Justice (Public Order) Act 1994 - Riot
• Alt 14 den Acht um Cheartas Coiriúil 1994 (Ord Poiblí) - Círéib
Again the offence can only be dealt with on indictment
Caithfear déileáil leis an gcion seo ar díotáil
B) Offences which may be tried summarily or by indictment at the request of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the judge or the accused
B) Cionta gur féidir iad a thriail go hachomair nó ar díotáil, ar iarratas ón Stiúrthóir Ionchúiseamh Poiblí, ón mbreitheamh nó ón duine cúisithe

Section 2 of the Criminal Justice Act 1951 as amended by the Criminal Justice (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1997 provides that offences listed in the First Schedule of the 1951 Act can be dealt with in the District Court if three conditions are met:

Forálann Alt 2 den Acht um Cheartas Coiriúil 1951, arna leasú ag an Acht um Cheartas Coiriúil 1997 (Forálacha Speisialta), gur féidir déileáil leis na cionta a luaitear sa Chéad Sceideal den Acht 1951, sa Chúirt Dúiche nuair a chomhlíontar an trí choinníoll a leanas:
The court is of the opinion that the facts proved or alleged amount to a minor offence which the court feels is fit to be tried summarily (in the District Court)
Bíonn an Chúirt den bharúil gur mionchion atá i gceist toisc na fíorais soiléire nó líomhanta atá ar fáil agus go bhféadfaí in ann an duine a thriail go hachomair (i gCúirt Dúiche)
The accused person, when told by the court of his/her right to be tried by a judge and a jury, does not object to being tried in the District Court, and
Níl an duine cúisithe i gcoinne trialach sa Chúirt Dúiche, nuair a thugtar faisnéis dó/di faoina c(h)earta i leith trialach os comhair breitheamh agus coiste dháréag
The Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) consents to the accused being tried summarily for such offence
Tugann Stiúrthóir Ionchúiseamh Poiblí (DPP) cead do na cúirteanna an duine cúisithe a thriail go hachomair i leith ciona dá leithéid
In practice, the judge looks to see what the DPP has directed and then asks the prosecuting Garda for an outline of the facts of the case
Déanann an breitheamh imscrúdú ar threoracha an DPP agus cuireann sé/sí ceist ar an Garda ionchúisimh achoimre a thabhairt ar fhíorais an cháis
The judge then decides whether or not they are willing to hear the case or send it forward to a higher court to be dealt with (indictment)
Ansin, caithfear cinneadh a dhéanamh an cás a thriail roimh an Chúirt Dúiche nó é a chur ar aghaidh go cúirt níos airde (ar díotáil)
If the judge decides to hear the case in the District Court the accused is given an opportunity to choose whether to be dealt with in the District Court or the Circuit Court
Má dhéantar an cás a thriail sa Chúirt Dúiche, is féidir leis an duine cúisithe roghnú a dhéanamh idir an Chúirt Dúiche agus an Chúirt Chuarda
Normally, if an accused is given this choice they elect to be dealt with in the District Court as the maximum penalty available to the District Judge is less than that available in the Circuit Court
De ghnáth, is í an Chúirt Dúiche a roghnaíonn an duine cúisithe chun a c(h)ás a thriail, toisc go mbíonn pionós níos lú i gceist sa Chúirt Dúiche, i gcomparáid leis an gCúirt Chuarda
Examples of some of the offences listed in the First Schedule are:
Is iad seo a leanas roinnt de na cionta a luaitear sa Chéad Sceideal:
• Offences under the Criminal Law Act 1997
• Cionta faoin Acht um Dhlí Choiriúil 1997
• Offences under the Criminal Law (Rape) (Amendment) Act 1990
• Cionta faoin Acht um Dhlí Choiriúil 1990 (Éigniú) (Leasú)
• Offences under the Criminal Justice (Theft and Fraud Offences) Act 2001
• Cionta faoin Acht um Cheartas Coiriúil 2001 (Cionta Gada agus Calaoise)
C) Offences which may be tried either summarily or on indictment at the option of the Director of Public Prosecutions, subject to the agreement of the District Court judge
C) Cionta gur féidir iad a thriail go hachomair nó ar díotáil, bunaithe ar rogha an Stiúrthóra Ionchúiseamh Poiblí, agus i gcomhaontú le breitheamh na Cúirte Dúiche
This procedure is the same as that outlined at (B) above but without the accused being given an option as to whether they want the case to be dealt with in the District or Circuit Court

Tá an nós imeachta céanna i gceist anseo, a shainmhínítear i (B) thuas, ach amháin nach mbíonn cead ag an duine cúisithe roghnú a dhéanamh idir an Chúirt Dúiche agus an Chúirt Chuarda chun a c(h)ás a thriail
The offences in this category are created by statute and the statute or piece of law states the different punishments on summary conviction and on indictment
Cruthaítear na cionta sa chatagóir seo de bhua reachta agus leagtar amach sa reacht nó san acht áirithe na pionóis dhifriúla a bhaineann le ciontú ar achomair nó ar díotáil
How this process works in practice is that the DPP issues instructions as to whether the offence should be dealt with in the District or Circuit Court
Mar chuid den phróiseas seo, eisíonn an DPP treoracha chun an cion a thriail sa Chúirt Dúiche nó sa Chúirt Chuarda

If the DPP directs summary disposal (District Court), the District Court judge hears a summary of the facts from the prosecuting Garda and then decide if they will allow the case to be dealt with in their court

Nuair a thugann an DPP treoir achomair (Cúirt Dúiche), déanann breitheamh na Cúirte Dúiche imscrúdú ar na bhfíorais ón Garda ionchúisimh chun cinneadh a dhéanamh an cás a thriail ina c(h)úirt féin nó i gcúirt eile

If the judge is not satisfied that the offence is a minor offence then they refuse jurisdiction (that is, refuses to deal with the case) and sends it forward to the Circuit Court to be dealt with on indictment
Má cheapann an breitheamh gur tromchion atá i gceist, ní ghlacann sé/sí le dlínse (ní ghlacann sé/sí leis an gcás) agus chuirtear é ar aghaidh chuig an Chúirt Chuarda chun é a thriail ar díotáil
Article 38.2 of the Constitution of Ireland sets out that minor offences may be tried in courts of summary jurisdiction, that is, the District Court
De réir Airteagail 38.2 de Bhunreacht na hÉireann féadtar mionchionta a thriail i gcúirteanna le dlínse achomair – an Chúirt Dúiche
There is no definition of what a minor offence is in the Constitution although they are most often set down by the actual law
Ní thugtar cur síos ar mhionchion i mBunreacht na hÉireann, ach déantar é sin san acht iomchuí don chuid is mó
The distinction between the constitutional concepts of minor and non-minor offences equates more or less with the statutory distinction drawn between summary and indictable offences
Tá an idirdhealú bunúsach céanna idir na coincheapa bunreachtúla, “mionchionta” agus “neamhmhionchionta”, agus idir na coincheapa reachtúla “cionta achomair” agus “cionta indíotáilte”
The Supreme Court has however considered the issue of what constitutes a minor offence
Leagadh amach sa Chúirt Uachtarach áfach cad é mionchion
The most important case in this area is a case called Melling v Ó Mathghamhna IR 1
Is é Melling v Ó Mathghamhna IR 1 an cás is tábhachtaí maidir leis an saincheist seo
In examining the criteria or rules when deciding whether an offence was minor the Supreme Court laid out the following test:
Úsáideann an Chúirt Uachtarach na tástálacha seo a leanas chun scrúdú a dhéanamh ar na critéirí nó rialacha chun a fháil amach an é mionchion atá i gceist:
• The severity or seriousness of the punishment
• Déine nó tromchúis an phionóis
• Moral guilt of the accused
• Ciontacht mhorálta an duine cúisithe
• The law in 1937 when the Constitution was adopted, and
• An dlí i 1937, nuair a glacadh leis an mBunreacht, agus
Of these four tests, it is undoubtable that the most important one is the severity or seriousness of the sentence
Cinnte, is í an tástáil is tábhachtaí ná tromchúis nó déine na breithe

All that can be said with certainty is that an offence is minor where the punishment is less than six months imprisonment (Conroy v Attorney General IR 411), whereas an offence is non-minor where the punishment is two years or more (Mallon v Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry 1 IR 517)

Is féidir linn a rá go bhfuil mionchion i gceist nuair a bhíonn ar dhuine níos lú ná 6 mhí a chaitheamh sa phríosún (Conroy v an tArd-Aighne IR 411), agus is neamhmhionchion é nuair a fhaigheann an duine cúisithe 2 bhliain nó níos mó sa phríosún (Mallon v an tAire Talmhaíochta, Bia agus Foraoiseachta 1 IR 517)
It appears, however, that the courts have come to the belief an offence with a maximum prison sentence of twelve months constitutes a minor offence
Is léir áfach, go gceapann na cúirteanna gur mionchion atá i gceist nuair a fhaigheann an duine cúisithe pianbhreith phríosúnachta de 12 mí nó íos lú
It can be said as a result that any offence that carries a penalty of more than twelve months imprisonment is considered a non-minor offence
Mar thoradh ar seo, is neamhmhionchion é nuair a bhíonn ar dhuine cúisithe níos mó ná 12 mí a chaitheamh i bpríosún
The Bail Act 1997 created a new distinction between serious and non-serious offences
Leagadh amach difríochtaí nua idir tromchionta agus neamhthromchionta san Acht um Bhannaí 1997
The Act allows bail to be refused where an accused is charged with a serious offence and it can be established that the accused is likely to commit further serious offences if released on bail

Tugann an Acht cead do na cúirteanna bannaí a dhiúltú i gcás tromchiona nó nuair a thaispeántar go bhfuil seans mór ann go mbeidh an duine cúisithe freagrach as tromchionta eile, má ligfear amach ar bhannaí iad
The Bail Act 1997 defines a serious offence as an offence for which a person, if convicted, could be imprisoned for 5 years or more
De réir an Achta um Bhannaí 1997, bíonn tromchion i gceist nuair a bhíonn ar an duine cúisithe 5 bliana nó níos mó a chaitheamh sa phríosún
Arrestable and non-arrestable offences
Cionta inghabhála agus neamhinghabhála

Just as the Bail Act 1997 created a distinction between serious and non-serious offences, the Criminal Law Act 1997 abolished the distinction between a felony and misdemeanour and created the arrestable/non-arrestable distinction

Cruthaíodh na téarmaí tromchionta agus neamhthromchionta san Acht um Bhannaí 1997, agus cuireadh deireadh le húsáid na téarmaí “feileonacht” agus “oilghníomh”, agus bunaíodh cionta inghabhála agus neamhinghabhála san Acht um Dhlí Choiriúil 1997
The Act defines an arrestable offence as an offence for which a person could be punished by imprisonment for 5 years or more, similar to the definition of a serious offence mentioned above
De réir an Achta, bíonn cion inghabhála i gceist nuair a bhíonn ar an duine cúisithe 5 bliana nó níos mó a chaitheamh sa phríosún. Tá an cion seo an-chosúil leis an tromchion thuasluaite
This distinction holds great importance for the Gardaí
Tá an difríocht seo an-tábhachtach do na Gardaí

Section 4 of the Criminal Law Act 1997 allows a Garda to arrest without warrant any person whom the Garda, with reasonable cause, believes to be guilty of committing or having committed an arrestable offence
Tugann Alt 4 den Acht um Dhlí Choiriúil 1997 cead do na Gardaí duine a ghabháil gan barántas nuair a bhíonn cúis réasúnach acu go bhfuil an duine seo ciontach as cion inghabhála

Any person arrested for such an arrestable offence (without a warrant) can be detained in a Garda station for a maximum period of 12 hours for questioning before being charged with an offence or being released
Nuair a ghabháltar duine de bharr ciona inghabhála (gan barántas gabháil), féadtar iad a ghabháil agus a choimeád i stáisiún na nGardaí ar feadh 12 uaire nó níos lú, chun iad a cheistiú
Also, if you remain silent when questioned by Gardaí in certain circumstances, inferences can be drawn from your silence in any proceedings against you for an arrestable offence
Má theipeann ort ceisteanna na nGardaí a fhreagairt i gcásanna áirithe, is féidir leis na Gardaí tátail a bhaint as seo má dhéantar an dlí a chur orthu de bharr ciona inghabhála
Further information on your right to silence is available here
Cliceáil anseo chun breis faisnéise a fháil ar do cheart chun tosta
